III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Program Statement.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
Description program statement which specifically addresses all of the
following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’
needs, implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of
residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Reports of concern for multiple runaway children who ultimately
become recovered by law enforcement. Often, the children are
untruthful with officers, combative and disobey direction given by
officers. There is a concern if the facility is fit to maintain the
safety of the children.
Investigation This complaint was received on 02/15/2024 via online agency
complaint.
I emailed and called Complainant on 02/16/2024, requesting
additional information regarding incidents and youths involved.
No additional information was provided.
Interviews:
I interviewed Director on 02/20/2024 at the agency. Director
reported the agency has several youths that AWOL frequently
and the staff are expected to make all efforts to maintain eyesight
of the youth. If youths leave the grounds, staff follow them as far
as possible without endangering the youth's safety. If staff lose
eyesight of them, the police are contacted, and a missing
person’s report is filed. Director said all staff follow the agency
policy to ensure the safety of the children when they leave the
campus without permission. Staff attempt to verbally redirect the
youths when they AWOL, but staff cannot use any form of
physical management to stop the youth from AWOLing. Methodist
is an open campus facility; the exit doors in the cottages are not
secure, and staff do not prevent children from leaving. Director
said the youths that frequently AWOL are Youth A, Youth B, Youth
C, and Youth D. Director said when youths return to campus, staff
have to take them to the police department to report their return,
2

but sometimes the youths refuse to go with staff to the police
department. Director has been in communication with Detective 2
to figure out a plan to document those incidents.
I interviewed Youth A on 02/20/2024 at the agency. Youth A is 14
years old, has been at the agency for 6 months, and is placed in
Harrison Cottage. Youth A reported there is usually two staff
members in the cottage. He admitted to leaving the cottage
without permission. He said staff try to talk to him and stop him
from AWOLing, but he has friends in the neighborhood and feels
it is safe for him to leave the campus. Youth A said staff follow
him on foot and sometimes they follow him in the agency van.
Youth A said when he returns to campus, staff search him by
emptying his pockets, and using a metal detector wand. Youth A
reported he gets enough food, has clean clothes and hygiene
products, and feels safe.
I interviewed Youth B on 02/20/2024 at the agency. Youth B is 17
years old, has been at the agency for one year, and is placed in
Juhnke Cottage. Youth B reported there is always two staff
members supervising, staff do try to redirect him from leaving,
and staff try to follow him to maintain line of sight. Youth B said he
gets enough to eat, takes his medication daily, participates in
weekly group and individual therapy, and feels safe. Youth B
denied having any concerns regarding staff or the agency.
I interviewed Youth C on 02/20/2024 at the agency. Youth C is 11
years old, has been at the agency for 7 months, and is placed in
Harrison Cottage. Youth C admitted he AWOLs a lot, because he
likes to go to the stores and walks around the neighborhood.
Youth C said staff do follow him, try to talk him out of leaving the
campus, and search him when he comes back to campus. Youth
C said when he AWOLs, staff do follow him on foot and
sometimes in the agency van to maintain line of sight. Youth C
said he gets enough to eat, all his needs are being met, and feels
safe.
I interviewed Youth D on 02/20/2024 at the agency. Youth D is 17
years old, has been at the agency for 4 months, and is placed in
Juhnke Cottage. Youth D admitted he AWOLs sometimes, and
staff do try to stop him by talking to him and following him. Youth
D expressed no concerns regarding the agency or staff and feels
safe. Youth D said staff search him after the AWOL using a metal
detector wand and emptying his pockets.
3

I interviewed Staff 1 on 02/20/2024 at the agency. Staff 1 has
been working at the agency for 4 months and has completed all
training including CPI. She works 2nd shift in Harrison Cottage.
She said there is always two staff and one supervisor in the
cottage. Staff 2 said when Youths AWOL, staff try to verbally
redirect youths to prevent them from leaving and will follow the
youth as far as possible as to not put the youth in danger. Staff
will follow the youth on foot or by using the agency van. If staff
cannot get them to come back, the staff will contact the
supervisor and file a police report. An incident report is also
written when a Youth AWOLs, the supervisor reviews this report,
and sends out notifications to the Parent/Guardian and Foster
Care Worker. Staff 1 reported no safety concerns for the youths.
I interviewed Supervisor 1 at the agency. Supervisor 1 has been
working at the agency for 12 years. Supervisor 1 reported staff
follow the agency policy and do everything they can to
discourage the youths from AWOLing. He said staff try verbal
redirection, will offer alternatives (such as going to the gym), staff
follow the youth as far as possible to maintain line of sight and to
ensure the youth is not put in danger. The staff always report the
AWOL to the supervisor, file a missing person report with the
police department and complete an incident report. He is not
aware of any incidents where youths left the campus and staff
didn’t follow them nor file any police reports. Supervisor 1 said if a
staff member is not available to follow a youth the supervisor or
director will follow the youth to ensure they have enough staff to
stay in ratio.
I interviewed Detective 1 with the Livonia Police Department via
telephone on 02/27/2024. Detective 1 said there is no police
reports or incidents involving youths at Methodist. He said his
main concern is staff do not prevent or stop youths from leaving
the campus.
I interviewed Detective 2 with Redford Police Department via
telephone on 03/06/2024. Detective 2 reported he does not have
concerns regarding the agency not reporting AWOLs. He said
they receive many calls from the agency for police assistance
due to the youths assaulting staff and destroying property at the
agency.
I interviewed Youth B’s Foster Care Worker (FCW) via telephone
on 2/20/2024. She reported the agency does notify her timely and
keeps her updated on Youth B’s behavior and AWOLs. FCW said
her only issue is the incident reports are handwritten and the writing
is not very clear, and reports need to be more detailed.
4

Documents Reviewed:
• Agency AWOL policy. Staff are expected to make all efforts
to maintain eyesight of the youth(s). If youths leave the
grounds, staff should get a van and follow them. If youths
AWOL but stay on campus and go into the woods, staff
should contact the supervisor, follow calmly on foot, and
verbally attempt to return them. Staff must follow youths as
far as possible without endangering their own safety. If
youths retreat further into the woods and staff lose eyesight
of them, the police should be contacted, a missing person’s
report filed, and when a youth returns to campus notify
police.
• Agency policy: Child Supervision: 2. Agency schedules staff
to maintain a 4:1 ratio. Staff strive to maintain this ratio,
though there will be times when staff cannot, such as when a
child goes AWOL, or during a restraint. This does not mean
that staff are out of ratio because there are ample staff
scheduled to respond to the child issues.
Analysis The agency is compliant with the rule based on interviews and
documentations reviewed confirmed staff follow agency policy
regarding youths’ safety and AWOLs. The agency is an open
campus, the exit doors in the cottages are not secure, and do not
prevent children from leaving. Further, staff are not permitted to
physically restrain children to prevent them from leaving.
It was recommended that Methodist’s Administration meet with the
local police to educate them on the agency program and policy.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
The agency was advised to ensure all incident reports include all
details of the incident and are written clearly.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
5

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
